docs.lead_paragraph: The blare of traffic is back. Sidewalks along Broadway are full -- the usual mass of people buying, selling, gawking, pushing, all at different speeds and in different directions. A small ark of animals has been rescued from a building on 44th Street, including 12 cats, 2 illegal ferrets, several goldfish, one cockatiel, a guinea pig, a gerbil and a hamster. Except for those areas in the shadow of the Conde Nast building, where loose scaffolding caused part of an elevator tower to break away a week ago, crashing into a residential hotel and killing an elderly woman, Times Square is almost back to normal. With most of the city's crossroads reopened, and with the breakaway scaffolding slowly being secured with what one television reporter called ''our giant nylon stocking,'' this is a good time to find out what really happened. Speculation is now focusing on the possibility that beams holding the scaffolding to the building on the 21st floor may not have been properly fastened by contractors working on the facade. Workers often remove the beams holding the elevator tower while they apply the facade. The question is whether someone neglected to re-attach the beams or whether they were somehow wrenched from the building in the accident.

headline.main: The Return, Almost, of Times Square

docs.abstract: Editorial urges New York City to insure that construction can safely proceed on Conde Nast building in Times Square following accident in which scaffolding collapsed; says its must make sure report on cause of accident is finished quickly and used to help prevent similar mishaps in high-density city (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Furthering a consolidation that has recently accelerated in the reinsurance industry, the Swiss Reinsurance Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Life Re Corporation for $95 a share, or about $1.8 billion, in cash. The purchase by Swiss Re, the world's second-largest reinsurance company behind Munich Reinsurance, is the third deal in the industry in little more than a month. Last week. Gerling A.G., the German insurer, bought the Constitution Reinsurance Corporation from Exor Group S.A., an investment company controlled by the Agnelli family of Italy, for $700 million. And in June the Berkshire Hathaway Corporation, the holding company run by Warren E. Buffett, bought the General Re Corporation, one of the world's largest reinsurers, for just under $22 billion.

headline.main: Life Re Agrees To Be Bought By Swiss Re

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Does It Matter Who Regulates Managed Care?'' (letters, July 27): I am the medical director of a health maintenance organization. Making H.M.O.'s liable for treatment decisions will not solve the alleged problem of patients' being denied access to appropriate care. It will only drive up premium costs and scare physician reviewers from participating in the health plans' review process.

headline.main: Mayor's Methadone Stance Risks Addicts' Health

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Kay Bailey Hutchison (Op-Ed, July 21) ignores the realities in the health insurance market. Employers have drastically cut the amount they are willing to provide to employees in health care insurance. This is done by limiting employee choice to lower-cost plans like health maintenance organizations and by increasing employee health-plan contributions.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The establishment of a health care identifier and resulting privacy concerns are well founded, but those concerns have been solved in other countries, notably Germany and France (Op-Ed, July 24). Both countries have strong privacy laws and have embraced smart-card technology. ''Smart'' health care cards remain under the control of the patient, who decides who will get access to the medical record.

headline.main: Does It Matter Who Regulates Managed Care?; 'Smart' Health Cards

docs.abstract: Health care consultant Udo Koellmann letter notes that Germany and France successfully use 'smart' health cards under control of the patient as ways of creating a health care identifier without sacrificing privacy (July 24 Op-Ed article)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Teachers Make Fight Over Contract a Very Public Issue'' (July 19), again you have damaged Middletown Township and its school system and have told only part of the story. Fifteen years ago, New Jersey schoolteachers were underpaid. But communities throughout New Jersey began to correct that problem. Over the next 12 years, salaries of Middletown teachers rose a compound 138 percent, versus 62.3 percent for the cost of living. The teachers make no contributions to their families' health insurance or to their pensions.
docs.abstract: Madeline Dale letter disputes July 19 article on teacher salary issues in Middletown Township, NJ (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the past few years the Federal Government and private researchers have issued a number of reports depicting dramatic improvement in the quality of life for America's black population. High school completion rates have reached parity with those of whites. Birth rates among single black women have hit a 40-year low. Homicide rates have declined to the levels of the 1960's. Poverty rates have dipped below 30 percent of black households for the first time in the country's history. The home ownership rate is up. The jobless rate is down. Somebody tell Julian Bond.

headline.main: The Nation; Good Times Are Bad For Interest Groups

docs.abstract: Advocacy groups from across political spectrum have issued dark assessments and dire warnings about current racial, moral, financial and social climate, even as country enjoys peace and prosperity and is arguably less racist, less sexist, less dangerous and less polluted than it has been in decades--and perhaps, ever; distance between dispassionate analysis and advocates' oratory raises question of how groups that see mission as correcting injustice handle good times; photo (M)
